p: Janek et al. [ 28] examined the antimicrobial and antiadhesive properties of trehalose lipids (TLs) against a number of pathogens. The authors concluded that TLs indicated the highest antimicrobial activity against Vibrio harveyi and Proteus vulgaris, as well as inhibited the growth of the yeast Candida albicans by 30%. Moreover, the authors observed a strong antiadhesive property, especially against C. albicans and Escherichia coli on polystyrene surfaces and silicone urethral catheters. According to the authors, their findings show that TLs could be successfully used as surface-coating agents.
